title: Chinese developer's assets frozen over $100m tax bill
text:
The Melbourne-based arm is called Hengyi and is developing more than 1000 apartments in a 72-storey tower in Swanston Street, Carlton.

Hengyi is also responsible for Pacifica, which will become New Zealand's highest residential tower at 178 metres in Auckland's CBD.

According to a Federal Court judgment, Ms Wang started in property development in Australia in 2010.

In 2014, she, Mr Chen and their children were granted permanent visas under Australia's business talent scheme.

Retail space available at the foot of Hengyi's Swanston tower. Supplied

The freezing order was made on October 28 and expires at 5pm today.

There are a number of reasons for being "satisfied there is a real risk of dissipation of assets", including Ms Wang's close ties with China, the judgment says.

"The amount of tax liability is very significant in circumstances where she has both the means and the motive to remove assets because of her control of each of the corporate entities and of the trusts of which those corporate entities are trustees," the documents say.

Advertisement

There is also evidence that Ms Wang made false statements in her income tax returns for the 2014 and 2015 income years about her interests in China by saying she did not have assets outside Australia valued at $50,000 or more or an interest in any foreign controlled company, the judgment says.

However, information obtained by the ATO in the course of its audit and review of Ms Wang's tax affairs for the 2014 income year show she held shares in foreign companies.

"There is also evidence that Ms Wang gave misleading information to the Australian Taxation Office concerning the funding of the purchase and development of the property at 199 William Street, Melbourne by Hengyi Australia, a company of which Ms Wang is a sole director and shareholder," the judgment says.

"The evidence discloses that Ms Wang has experience in international financial dealings and a history of transferring assets and liabilities between related parties. She also has a history of not putting commercial agreements between related parties into writing."
description: The Federal Court has frozen more than $100 million in assets belonging to Chinese businesswoman Min Wang, whose company is redeveloping the Swanston Central residential precinct in Melbourne.
